Award.AwardTitle: Community Meeting on Scalable Data Publication Infrastructure

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Disciplinary (non-institutional) data repositories have much higher rates of adoption than Institutional Repositories (IRs) in part because they are directly integrated with key points in researcher workflows, particularly during the publishing of scientific articles. But community repositories lack partnerships with institutional expertise found in librarians and data curators. This project addresses researcher need through taking the first steps in an open, community-supported initiative in research data curation and publishing. To effectively leverage institutional knowledge and serve researchers as end users, more and varied types of institutions need to have a say in the values and necessities. To build broad community support, this invitational workshop will explore community requirements, identify impediments, study sustainable business models, and make recommendations regarding the widespread promotion and adoption of effective, scalable, and sustainable institutional data publication infrastructure.

This project is supported by the National Science Foundation?s Public Access Initiative which is managed by the NSF Office of Advanced Cyberinfrastructure on behalf of the Foundation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on bringing together researchers to discuss how open data publishing, compliant with federal mandates, can be researcher-led and scalable for researcher needs. Our one-day workshop held at National Center for Ecological Analysis and Synthesis (NCEAS) consisted of both early career and senior researchers in the ecology and environmental sciences. These specific science communities were chosen according to their strong background in open data policies and practices, and their leadership in the early founding of Dryad (https://datadryad.org). 

 

One of our goals was to understand what researchers believe are necessary requirements for making data publishing as easy as possible and what can make published data primed for re-use. Through a series of facilitated partner and group activities, including brainstorming and prioritization of features, researchers presented on what data publishing platforms should consider to better accommodate their research questions and workflows. Another goal was to understand what makes a community and platform ?researcher-led?. Facilitating an open conversation around what resonates with varying lab practices and incentives, we were able to better understand steps that we can take as infrastructure providers and community builders to ensure researchers are not only included but leading future directions.

 

Aligning with a representative sub-section of the scientific research community allows for us to build more functional, useful, and less duplicative systems that can promote large scale adoption of both publishing and re-using research data. Garnering researcher buy-in effectively moves the idea of data publishing away from it being solely a requirement, towards an adopted and useful practice that can accelerate scientific discovery and transparency.
